case_vignette: A 22-year-old woman at 30 weeks gestation presents to the obstetrician with the sudden onset of fever, headache, anorexia, fatigue, and malaise. She mentioned that she had eaten ice cream 3 days ago. Blood cultures show gram-positive rods that are catalase-positive and display distinctive tumbling motility in liquid medium.
question: What is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Infectious Diseases. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.

I've suddenly come down with a fever, a headache, I'm not feeling like eating, feeling really tired, and just generally unwell.
Have you had any recent travel or exposure to someone who has been sick?
No recent travel or known exposure to sick people, but I did eat ice cream 3 days ago.
Have you had any recent changes in your weight or appetite?
I'm not really feeling like eating recently.
Have you had any recent changes in your sleep patterns or sleep quality?
I haven't mentioned anything about changes in my sleep patterns or sleep quality.
Have you had any recent changes in your stress levels or work schedule?
I haven't mentioned anything about changes in my stress levels or work schedule.
Have you had any recent changes in your medication or supplements?
I haven't mentioned taking any medications or supplements recently.
Have you had any recent changes in your family history or medical history?
I haven't mentioned any changes in my family or medical history.
Final Diagnosis: Influenza.
